questions.question_text:
A company has created a policy to allow employees to use their personally owned devices. The Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) is getting reports of company data appearing on unapproved forums and an increase in theft of personal electronic devices.
Which of the following security controls would BEST reduce the risk of exposure?

choices.A: Disk encryption on the local drive
choices.B: Group policy to enforce failed login lockout

discussion.content:
The question key is « ... company data appearing on unapproved forums..«
Based on the answers, criptography could be the best selection.
A.

comments.content:
Without strong authentication, encryption would not do much good. If I steal your phone, and crack your password, I have access to all of your data, whether the drive is encrypted or not. I might even be able to decrypt the drive, once I'm logged in.
That is why, it seemed to me like multifactor authentication might also be a good answer. I might be able to crack your password, but fingerprint would be more difficult.

discussion.content: It's definitely A, none of the other options are going to help with theft a device, specifically related to the company data on the device.

A
The spill is specifically related to an increase in device theft. Enforcing disk encryption on the devices will prevent someone stealing a drive and scraping the data out of the drive. They'll have to guess how to log in first. It's not a great question, but the given answer is definitely correct.

"Given that the network requires 802.1X EAP-PEAP to identify and authenticate devices, which of the following should the security administrator do to integrate the new employees' devices into the network securely?"

New employee device need to integrate with 802.1X EAP-PEAP so need the supplicant for it.
D would be the answer

C.

"PEAP—Protected EAP (PEAP) is an 802.1x authentication method that uses server-side public key certificates to authenticate clients with server. The PEAP authentication creates an encrypted SSL / TLS tunnel between the client and the authentication server. The exchange of information is encrypted and stored in the tunnel ensuring the user credentials are kept secure." (https://www.arubanetworks.com/techdocs/ArubaOS_60/UserGuide/802.1x.php#:~:text=PEAP%E2%80%94Protected%20EAP%20(PEAP),client%20and%20the%20authentication%20server.)

Self-signed certificates are not an issue since companies with PKI will often have the CA self-sign its own certificate.

comments.content: I think PEAP now uses TLS, not SSL. Also, I think EAP-PEAP, only pertain to wireless networking.

discussion.content: Disagree with B. Given answer is correct. Doing a "unique public/private key pair to each new employee's device" would be a nightmare. For use inside their own network a self signed cert is fine.
What? Lol self-signed certs are not how you securely connect to anything. The only answer that makes sense is B, use unique public/private key pairs...

choices.A: Distribute a NAC client and use the client to push the company's private key to all the new devices.
choices.B: Distribute the device connection policy and a unique public/private key pair to each new employee's device.
choices.C: Install a self-signed SSL certificate on the company's RADIUS server and distribute the certificate's public key to all new client devices.
choices.D: Install an 802.1X supplicant on all new devices and let each device generate a self-signed certificate to use for network access.

questions.question_text:
Ann, a terminated employee, left personal photos on a company-issued laptop and no longer has access to them. Ann emails her previous manager and asks to get her personal photos back.
Which of the following BEST describes how the manager should respond?

choices.D: Deleting the UEFI boot loaders from each HDD.
choices.B: Physically disabling the HDDs by removing the drive head.
choices.C: Demagnetizing the hard drive using a degausser.
choices.A: Overwriting all HDD blocks with an alternating series of data.

questions.question_text:
During the decommissioning phase of a hardware project, a security administrator is tasked with ensuring no sensitive data is released inadvertently. All paper records are scheduled to be shredded in a crosscut shredder, and the waste will be burned. The system drives and removable media have been removed prior to e-cycling the hardware.
Which of the following would ensure no data is recovered from the system drives once they are disposed of?

discussion.content:
C. Demagnetizing the hard drive using a degausser.

The system drives and removable media were removed from the rest of the hardware. The rest of the hardware is being e-cycled (reused), but the drives that were removed need to be demagnetized using a degausser.

Yall missed the word e-cycling, the HDDs are going to be used again. 

A.

comments.content: It's not going to be reused, e-cycling relates to it's disposal.

I don't think that answer is A, because the HDDs are not going to be used again. The rest of the hardware that it was removed from is what is being e-cycled. However, a quick Google search indicates that e-cycling IS reuse of electronic equipment.

discussion.content:
Since it's explained why it's A, here's why it's not A, B, or D. It's not A, because residual data can remain after overwriting data. It's not B, because
physically disabled hard drives can be repaired. D is probably the worst answer, because HDD's without boot loaders can actually be used like removable
media if you use a SATA to USB cable.

To reiterate, degaussing is actually destroying the hard drive and bricking it from ever being used again. Not only can data not even be read, but you can't even use it in the future as an empty drive.

C.
Degaussing cannot "miss some things," you destroy the disk plates with a giant magnet. Degaussing is as effective as crushing the disk with a steam roller.
Multi-pass block overwrites can miss things, though. Degaussing or physically destroying the disks are the two ways to ensure all data on the disk is destroyed.

Maybe: A. Overwriting all HDD blocks with an alternating series of data?
Seems like this might be better than degaussing. I think degaussing can miss some things.
